title: Grieving families in financial difficulty could face further heartache under Government plans to slash "lifeline" payments
text:
News Grieving families in financial difficulty could face further heartache under Government plans to slash "lifeline" payments MPs are set to debate changes to the Widowed Parent’s Allowance ­payments, currently made until dependant children leave full-time education Share Georgia Elms learned she was expecting her second child the day after her husband died (Photo: Daily Mirror) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Bereaved families left struggling financially face further hardship under Government plans to slash the Widowed Parent’s Allowance. 
MPs will tomorrow debate changes to the ­payments, currently made until dependant children leave full-time education. 
But from April 6, parents could receive just 18 months’ support. 
Childhood Bereavement Network warned of a “significant impact on grieving families”, adding: “It may force parents to increase working hours, before their children are ready for them to be less available.” 
Parents get a £2,000 tax-free lump sum then up to £112.55, taxable, weekly. 
This will change to £3,500 but then £350 monthly for 18 months. Read More Thousands of widows will see benefits cut under Universal Credit 
CBN found the average claim lasted five to six years, so 75% of parents may lose up to £17,000. 
Widowed and Young charity’s Georgia Elms, who learned she was expecting her second child the day after her husband died, said: “If I’d been given the allowance for 18 months, it would’ve stopped when my child was 10 months old. The hardship of losing your partner isn’t just over after 18 months.” Like us on Facebook
